content.text: Initial test results for the pedestrian detection model on nighttime datasets show a precision drop of 12%. We need to debug this ASAP.
Is this specific to urban environments, or does it occur in rural datasets as well?
It’s predominantly urban datasets with a lot of artificial lighting.
Could this be related to glare from headlights affecting the bounding box accuracy?
I’ve uploaded a Confluence page with edge cases for pedestrian detection in heavy rain: https://confluence.nvidia.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=567891. Let’s add more scenarios if needed.
Thanks, Samantha. I’ll add notes from the logs of the Seattle dataset.
Quick observation: The model tends to overpredict pedestrians when shadows from parked vehicles overlap with crosswalks.
Do we have a fallback mechanism to flag areas of high uncertainty for manual review?
Not yet, but I’ll work on adding uncertainty metrics to the next iteration.
I’ve flagged several misclassifications involving pedestrians standing near large advertisements with human images. This seems to confuse the model.
Heads-up: I’ve optimized the model’s preprocessing pipeline for night and low-light conditions. Early tests show a 7% improvement in recall.
That’s great! Do you think these improvements will generalize to rain datasets as well?
I’m running validations now to confirm. Should have results by EOD.
Do we have an update on integrating thermal imaging for better pedestrian detection at night?
The hardware compatibility tests are complete. We can begin pipeline integration this week.
I’ve updated the bug tracker with cases involving misdetections in low-contrast environments. Here’s the link: https://jira.nvidia.com/browse/PDAV-234.
Quick note: The vehicle’s edge cameras are underperforming in high-speed scenarios. Adding this to the QA checklist for validation.
Reminder: We need to finalize the training dataset for next week’s model retraining. Please review the current dataset by Wednesday.
The misidentification rate in the VIP lanes is higher than expected. We might need to adjust thresholds for this segment.
Does this issue persist across all cameras or only specific checkpoints?
Mostly at Gate B cameras. I’ll check the calibration settings for those.
Do we have any updates from the stakeholder meeting on whether to enable thermal imaging integration?
They’re leaning toward a pilot for high-traffic zones, especially during international arrivals.
We’re seeing delays in image processing at terminals with older hardware. Should we look into edge device optimizations?
Yes, I’ll revisit the TensorRT optimization pipeline and see if we can push more improvements.
Would splitting the workload across devices be feasible in the current setup?
I’ve created a heatmap visualization of areas with the most frequent misidentifications. It’s uploaded to Notion: https://notion.nvidia.com/face-recognition/heatmap.
Thanks, Maria. Let’s analyze whether these are camera-related or subject-specific issues.
Are we accounting for varying cultural norms in face coverings? This might impact results in international zones.
Good point. We could augment the dataset with more diverse examples for better handling.
I’ll tag the data science team to prioritize this for the next dataset iteration.
The gate-side kiosks are reporting a higher-than-normal error rate for non-standard passport photos. We might need better preprocessing here.
Is this linked to older passport photo formats, or just poor image quality?
It seems to be a mix of both. I’ll propose some enhancements to the image preprocessing module.
The fallback mechanism for failed identifications has improved workflow efficiency by 8%. QA results are on Confluence: https://confluence.nvidia.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=998822.
That’s promising! Let’s push these updates into the deployment pipeline.
Should we coordinate with customs to better understand their requirements for integrating facial recognition?
Yes, a joint session would help align on expectations and constraints.
I’ll draft an agenda and propose some meeting times.
FYI, I’ve updated the GitHub repo with the latest fallback mechanism code: https://github.com/nvidia/face-recognition/commit/fallback-update.
The updated deployment dashboard for airport facial recognition has been finalized. It includes per-gate performance metrics.
Can we add an alert system for gates consistently underperforming?
Great idea. I’ll add that to the backlog.
I pushed the initial pre-trained weights for the anomaly detection model. You can check them here: https://github.com/nvidia/retail-safety/commit/a1b2c3d. Please review.
Thanks, Arjun! Are these based on the dataset from last week’s deployment in San Jose?
Yes, I trained them on the refined dataset from the San Jose trial. The updated Confluence doc has all the preprocessing details: https://confluence.nvidia.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=123456.
Looks good! Do you want me to run additional tests on the Seattle dataset for validation?
Yes, please. That would be great. Let’s see how consistent the results are across both datasets.

Heads-up: Jira issue SAFETY-42 (https://jira.nvidia.com/browse/SAFETY-42) is still open. It’s blocking the deployment for the anomaly heatmap overlay. @arjun.mehta, do you think we can close this today?
I’m on it. Just need to validate the bounding box alignment on the demo footage.
Update: I’ve tested it, and it looks good. Closing the ticket now.
Thanks! Can you update the Confluence page with the details?
Sure. I’ll add a summary under the bug fixes section.
Quick question: Did anyone else notice that some detection bounding boxes jitter during movement? It seems related to the temporal smoothing logic.
@diana.lee It’s been flagged in Jira as SAFETY-48. I suspect the Kalman filter parameters might need adjustment.
I can help tweak the parameters if needed. Let’s ensure this is fixed before the next deployment.
Thanks, James. I’ll ping you once I’ve isolated the specific frames causing the issue.
I added a new section in the Notion workspace for deployment metrics: https://notion.nvidia.com/retail-safety/metrics-dashboard. Please let me know if anything’s missing.
Got it. Thanks, Priya. I’ll cross-check these with our current TensorBoard logs.
Looks great, Priya. We might want to add latency metrics to this as well.
Good idea, Diana. I’ll make a note and include that in the next iteration.

FYI: I’ve created a Confluence page summarizing the key takeaways from yesterday’s meeting. Link: https://confluence.nvidia.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=654321. Let’s finalize the next steps for the Dallas deployment.
Does anyone have suggestions on how to improve inference speed for edge devices? We’re running into latency issues with the Jetson Xavier NX.
@arjun.mehta Are you using TensorRT for optimization? It usually helps a lot with speedups.
@diana.lee Yep, but I think the issue might be with the post-processing. I’ll debug further and update Jira.
@arjun.mehta I think we had a similar issue on the face recognition project. Check out this GitHub commit for reference: https://github.com/nvidia/face-recognition/commit/d4e5f6g.
Reminder: Let’s sync up tomorrow to discuss the safety metric thresholds for the Dallas deployment. Should we stick to 90% accuracy, or aim higher?
We might be able to push to 92% with some additional training tweaks. Let’s discuss at the sync-up.
@james.wu, should we get feedback from the QA team on the thresholds? They might have additional insights.
@diana.lee Good idea. I’ll reach out to QA and loop them into the discussion tomorrow.
I noticed the issue with the bounding box jitter reappearing in the safety-analysis module under high-density scenarios. I’ve reopened Jira ticket SAFETY-223.
Thanks for catching that, Arjun. Was it tied to specific hardware setups or software configurations?
Mostly on older Jetson Nano devices during simultaneous inference tasks.
I’ve seen similar behavior in the face-recognition-airports module when processing partially occluded faces. Could it be related?
Possibly. I’ll cross-check the alignment between these two modules and see if there’s a shared dependency.
I’ve updated the Confluence page with details on the fallback issue in person detection during thermal imaging tests: https://confluence.nvidia.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=911233.
Thanks, Maria. I’ll check if those fallback edge cases are also triggering the jitter issue.
The automated deployment script for bug fixes in the face-recognition-airports project failed last night. I’ve logged this as BUG-324.
I’ll rerun the script with additional logging to see where it’s failing.
Could it be related to the recent update in the Jenkins pipeline for the airports module?
Potentially. I’ll verify the configurations and report back.
The person-detection-autonomous-vehicles module is showing inconsistent latency during fog simulations. I’ve flagged this in Jira as BUG-407.
Noted. I’ll rerun those simulations and profile the preprocessing pipeline to isolate the bottleneck.
The GitHub repo for the deepfake-detection project is missing the latest dependency updates. I’ll push a patch shortly.
Thanks, Michael. Let’s ensure the CI/CD pipeline triggers validation checks after the patch.
The anomaly-detection script for the safety-analysis module is crashing when handling dense data streams. I’ve logged it as BUG-431.
Could be a memory allocation issue. I’ll monitor the runtime metrics and report back.
I’ve updated the QA tracker with edge cases where person detection fails under overlapping shadows. QA results are available here: https://notion.nvidia.com/qa-results-tracker.
Thanks, Maria. I’ll use these cases to test the latest preprocessing updates.
I noticed a recurring issue with the deepfake-detection dashboard not updating in real-time. I’ll debug the front-end rendering scripts.
The latest bug fixes in the airports module have improved latency by 12%. Let’s validate this in the next stakeholder demo.
